Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides participant support to a conference titled "Equidistribution, Invariant Measures and Applications", to be held on May 19 - May 24, 2019 at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. The theory of actions of groups generated by unipotent elements also known as Ratner theory is a cornerstone of modern ergodic theory. The goal of the conference is to review the recent developments in the field and to set up new directions.

The main topics of the conference will be unipotent flows and their applications to counting and equidistribution; diagonal flows on homogenous spaces, and their applications in arithmetic and beyond; measure and orbit classification results for dynamics on moduli spaces of abelian and quadratic differentials; stationary measures and associated random walks in the homogeneous and non-homogeneous spaces. The conference structure will include mini-courses, lectures, and times for discussion and collaboration. More details about the conference could be found at http://ias.huji.ac.il/22midrashamathematicae .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant was supporting the US participants of the conference Equidistribution, Invariant measures and applications.

The theory of actions of groups generated by unipotent elements also known as Ratner theory is a cornerstone of modern ergodic theory. In her seminal work Marina Ratner was able to provide the classification of both orbit closures and invariant measures for unipotent actions on homogenous spaces. The theory has deep connections to many areas of mathematics including Lie groups, number theory, geometry, and mathematical physics. 

Several recent breakthroughs have dramatically increased the scope of the theory allowing to treat both larger classes of groups and non-homogenous actions. Currently Ratner theory is one of the most vigorous branches of modern mathematics as can be evidenced by recent Fields medals awarded to Elon Lindenstrauss and Maryam Mirzakhani and Clay Research awards given to Yves Benoist and Jean-François Quint and to Maryam Mirzakhani. Important recent advances include the solution of Zimmer Conjecture by Aaron Brown, David Fisher and  Sebastian Hurtado and measure rigidity results for random diffeomorphisms by Aaron Brown and Federico Rodriguez Hertz. The goal of the conference is to review the recent developments in the field and to set up new directions. The main topics of the conference were unipotent flows and their applications to counting and equidistributions; diagonal flows on homogenous spaces, and their applications in arithmetic and beyond; measure and orbit classification results for dynamics on moduli spaces of abelian and quadratic differentials; stationary measures and associated random walks in the homogeneous and non-homogeneous spaces.

The grant supported the participations of 11 US scientists, most of them either an early career mathematicians or members of underrepresented groups.

This conference helped young US participants to learn about new advances in this rapidly growing field. Thus the conference played an important role in maintaining the US leadership in the field of dynamics. In addition, the conference will provided a special opportunity for US participants to make and renew international contacts and to be exposed to intense interaction with leading mathematicians across continents and generations.
